title: 109_hr5643
content: The Act is titled the "Energy Technology Transfer Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Energy Technology Transfer Act" defines key terms such as Cooperative Extension, Department of Energy, energy supply research and development programs, and institution of higher education. The curr_chunk defines terms related to higher education institutions and national laboratories under the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the Energy Policy Act of 2005. Key terms include land-grant colleges and universities, National Laboratory, and Secretary of Energy. The curr_chunk simply states "SEC. 3. PROGRAM." The Secretary will award grants to conduct activities transferring knowledge about advanced energy technologies to various entities, requiring grant applicants to already operate an outreach program. Grant applicants must have an existing outreach program focused on advanced energy technologies to be eligible for funds. The funds can be used for developing informational materials, demonstrating energy-efficient technologies, conducting seminars and workshops, and providing onsite energy evaluations. The applicant seeking funding under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary, including a description of their current outreach program and why it is capable of transferring energy-efficient technologies. The Secretary may also hire experts in energy-efficient technologies to carry out various activities to accomplish the purposes of the Act. The applicant must submit an application describing their outreach program's ability to transfer advanced energy technologies efficiently. The Secretary will evaluate the application based on the proposed activities, target end-users, alignment with energy needs, and program success assessment. The Secretary evaluates applicants based on their ability to carry out the proposed program effectively, the appropriateness of their outreach program, and the potential for their activities to be expanded or serve as a model. Awards prioritize knowledge transfer of various technologies and geographic areas, as well as applicants that fill gaps in existing programs. The Secretary evaluates applicants based on their ability to carry out the proposed program effectively, the appropriateness of their outreach program, and the potential for their activities to be expanded or serve as a model. Awards prioritize knowledge transfer of various technologies and geographic areas, as well as applicants that fill gaps in existing programs. Cost sharing is required for commercial application activities, and grants awarded under this Act are for a 5-year period, with evaluations conducted in the third year to determine grantee success. Grants may be extended for an additional 3 years if the evaluation is positive. The grantee may receive an extension for up to 3 additional years beyond the original term, with a limit of 11 years of support without reapplying. Technical assistance on advanced energy technologies can be provided by the Secretary and National Laboratories. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of Appropriations for the Secretary for this section are as follows: $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, $27,375,000 for fiscal year 2009, $30,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $32,900,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $36,000,000 for fiscal year 2012.
